Blekkan Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Investigation Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Department of Chemical Engineering, Sem Sælands vei 4, Trondheim 7491, Norway Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU) Department of Chemical Engineering Sem Sælands vei 4 Trondheim 7491 Norway Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Department of Chemical Engineering, Sem Sælands vei 4, 7491, Trondheim, Norway ⁎ Corresponding author. The manganese promotion of cobalt−based catalysts for the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis was investigated using four different supports. Different loadings of manganese were deposited on the catalysts using incipient wetness impregnation before the impregnation of cobalt and rhenium. All the Mn-promoted catalysts exhibited an increase in chain growth probability and olefin content in the products. This enhanced C5+ selectivity is attributed mainly to decreased methane production. The promotion of the catalytic activity was dependent on the support material. On γ−Al2O3 the catalyst activity increased with increasing manganese loading. Using a narrow pore silica support (SiO2−N) a maximum in the activity was found at an intermediate manganese loading. Further addition of Mn decreased the activity and worsened the product distribution with an increase in methane selectivity. The catalysts supported on TiO2 and wide pore silica (SiO2−W), did not show major activity changes with Mn addition. The addition of Mn decreased the metallic surface area in most cases, indicating blocking of Co sites. The pore structure and the metal−support interactions play a role in how the Mn and Co are dispersed, yielding enhanced or inhibited activity. The origin of the promotion was investigated with CO and syngas adsorption experiments coupled with recording DRIFTS spectra. The results indicated a decrease in CO bond energy due to an increase in electron density of the Co with the Mn addition. The electronic effect appeared to be in balance with the site blocking of Mn. Therefore, choice of support and preparation conditions of the materials are important. Graphical Abstract Keywords Fischer-Tropsch Biomass to liquids Cobalt Manganese Support Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The increasing global demand for sustainable and cleaner energy sources [1] has heightened interest in the Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) as a viable route for the production of chemicals and green fuels from syngas via biomass gasification. Cobalt−based catalysts have emerged as a preferred choice for FTS due to their high conversion per pass and stability, high selectivity towards long−chain alkanes, and low production of undesired products compared with Fe [2–7]. However, in order to achieve a feasible biomass−to−liquids process, it is necessary to improve the performance of the Co catalysts. For that purpose, the addition of promoters has been a key area of research to enhance the activity and/or modify the product distribution. On one hand, the addition of small amounts of noble metals as promoters to the Co catalysts is a standard practice to enhance active metal dispersion, reducibility or intrinsic activity [8–13]. On the other hand, the use of oxide promoters has confirmed their effectiveness as structural and electronic promoters [14–21]. From these two groups, Re and Mn are interesting choices for promoting the Co catalysts. Re has proven to effectively increase the reducibility and dispersion of Co in the support material, yielding a higher intrinsic catalytic activity [11–13,19,22]. The addition of Mn has been studied widely as a promoter for Co catalysts in FTS. However, the effect of this promoter is dependent on the conditions of the study. The addition of Mn has been shown to be detrimental for the catalytic activity, as well as having a positive effect or not having any effect at all. Morales et al. [18,23–27] performed an extensive study on the Mn promotion of Co on titania support. Their research showed that Mn did not affect the activity but increased the selectivity to C5+ products accompanied by a decrease in the cobalt reducibility. In addition, their study showed the importance of the preparation method of the catalysts by two different syntheses: incipient wetness impregnation and homogeneous deposition precipitation (HDP). They concluded in their study, based on the adsorption properties obtained by DRIFTS, that the addition of Mn withdraws electron density from the Co resulting in a lower hydrogenation rate. On the other hand, Den Brejeen et al. studied a similar catalyst supported on SiO2 [28]. Their study showed that the ratio of Mn:Co and the preparation method were vital in order to achieve an enhanced catalyst. Higher Mn loadings led to a decrease in activity due to blocking of the Co surface. However, they also observed an increase in chain growth probability. Johnson et al. also studied the Co−Mn−SiO2 catalytic system [29] and found that most likely the origin of the Mn promotion was in the interphase between Co−Mn. Pedersen et al. [30] studied the promotion on catalysts supported on Al2O3 observing that how the materials were loaded in the support had a pronounced effect on the activity, and the same authors found theoretically (using DFT calculations) that Mn decreased the CO dissociation barrier. Recently, Tucker et al. [33] points to structural and geometric effects, reporting that Mn leads to reduced reducibility and dispersion but increases activity and selectivity due to enhanced removal of oxygen from the surface of cobalt-alumina catalysts. In contrast; van Koppen et al. [34] investigated manganese and platinum-promoted silica-supported cobalt, and found that addition of Mn leads to enhanced cobalt dispersion. This leads to stronger deactivation from formed water at high CO conversion due to the formation of cobalt silicates, but Mn stabilises the catalysts against sintering. Vasiliadis et al. [35] recently reported operando DRIFTS showing that Mn added to a cobalt/alumina catalyst resulted in a red-shift for the bridged and linear CO species, in line with weakening of the CO bond. In this work, the role of the support material on the Mn promotion has been explored. Different Mn loadings were studied using four different support materials in order to understand how the addition of Mn influences the catalytic activity of the Co catalysts. For that purpose, the same preparation method was employed for all samples in order to remove its effect and isolate the support dependency. The findings provide insights into the optimal Mn loading and mechanistic aspects of its promotion effect, contributing to the development of more efficient cobalt−based catalysts for industrial FTS applications. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of 11 cobalt−based catalysts were prepared with 15 wt% Co, 0.5 wt% Re on 4 different commercial supports; γ−alumina (Sasol Puralox SCCa 45/190), two silica gels with different pore size, SiO2−N (MERCK 288594 and SiO2−W (Davisil Grade 62) and titania (Degussa P − 25). Three different Mn loadings were studied per catalyst with 1.75, 3.75 and 5 % and compared with the same catalysts without Mn addition. The preparation of the Mn−CoRe catalysts was carried out through two subsequent incipient wetness impregnations with water as the solvent, first impregnating Mn (using Mn(NO3)2·4 H2O as the precursor) and subsequently co−impregnating Co (Co(NO3)2·6 H2O) and Re (HReO4), following the method described by Pedersen et al. [8,30–32]. For the catalysts without added Mn, a regular co−impregnation of Co and Re was carried out. 2.2 Fischer-Tropsch synthesis The Fischer-Tropsch synthesis was conducted in a fixed−bed reactor (stainless−steel, i.d. 10 mm) at 240 ºC and 5 bar. The catalyst (1 g, 54 −90 μm) was diluted with SiC (19 g, 90 −250 μm) to even out the temperature gradients along the reactor. Prior to the FTS, the catalysts underwent in−situ reduction by flowing a mixture of 125 −125 ml/min of H2−He for 10 h at 350 ºC (heating rate 1 ºC/min). Following reduction, the temperature was adjusted to 180 ºC, and the reactor was pressurized to 5 bar with He. The flow was switched to 250 mlN/min of synthesis gas with a H2:CO ratio of 1.7, containing 3 % of N2 serving as the internal standard for analysis and mass balance calculations. The temperature was then ramped to 230 ºC (20 ºC/min) and eventually to the reaction temperature of 240 ºC (5 ºC/min). Heavy hydrocarbons were collected in a hot trap (∼90 ºC), while liquid products were collected in a cold trap (∼25 ºC). Gas products were analyzed by an Agilent 6890 N gas chromatograph equipped with two columns: a Carbosieve with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) for permanent gases and an Al2O3−PLOT with a flame ionization detector (FID) for light hydrocarbons. Activity is reported in site−time yield (s−1) and CO conversion. Following the first 24 h on stream, CO conversion was adjusted to ∼50 % (± 5 %) by modifying the space velocity to compare the product distribution. Selectivity is reported in terms of CH4, C2-4 alpha olefins, C2-4 paraffins, and C5+hydrocarbons, based on the assumption that C1−C4 hydrocarbons are recovered in the gas phase following condensation of the liquids. 2.3 N2 volumetric adsorption Surface area, average pore size, and pore volume measurements were conducted using a Tristar 3000 via volumetric nitrogen adsorption−desorption. Prior to analysis, the samples (∼200 mg) underwent overnight degassing at 200 ºC. Surface area was determined using the Brunauer−Emmet−Teller (BET) equation, while pore size and pore volume were assessed utilizing the Barret−Joyner−Halenda (BJH) method on the nitrogen desorption branch. 2.4 H2 chemisorption H2 chemisorption was measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2010. The samples (∼200 mg) underwent evacuation at 40 ºC overnight and in situ reduction with H2 at 350 ºC (3 ºC/min) for 10 h. Subsequently, the samples were evacuated for 1 h at 300 ºC and then cooled to 40 ºC. The adsorption isotherm was measured between 0.01 −0.67 bar. The volume of H2 chemisorbed was determined by extrapolating the linear portion of the isotherm to zero pressure. Metallic dispersion was calculated under the assumption that one atom of H bonds to one surface Co atom and that only Co contributes to the volume of H2 adsorbed. The particle size was calculated by Eq. (1) assuming spherical and uniform Co particles with a site density of 14.6 atoms/nm2. (1) D = 96 d Where D is the metallic dispersion (%) and d is the Co particle size (nm). 2.5 X-ray diffraction X-ray diffraction was measured in a Bruker D8 DaVinci X-ray diffractometer instrument with CuKα radiation with the calcined catalysts. The crystallite size was obtained by the Scherrer equation from the most intense peak. The Co oxide crystallite size was corrected to metallic Co according to the relative molar volume [10] resulting in the following Eq. (2): (2) d = 0.8 · d Co 3 O 4 Where d is the metallic cobalt crystallite size and d Co 3 O 4 is the cobalt oxide crystallite size. 2.6 Temperature-programmed reduction Temperature−programmed reduction (TPR) was carried out in an Altamira−300RHP. The catalysts (∼100 mg) were degassed at 200 ºC for two hours and cooled to room temperature. The sample was then heated to 700 ºC and held for 1 h (10 ºC/min) in 50 ml/min gas flow consisting of 7 % hydrogen in Argon. The H2 consumption was measured by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.7 DRIFTS The CO adsorption was studied by Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy in a Thermo Fisher Scientific Nicolet iS50. A KBr beam splitter was used to obtain spectra in the range of 4000 −650 cm−1 with 64 scans for each spectrum. Around 30 mg of sample were place in the cell and reduced in−situ in a mixture of H2/He (20/20 ml/min) at 400 ºC for 4 h. From this point, two different experiments were conducted: CO adsorption and operando DRIFTS during Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. All the experiments were carried out at 1 bar. For the CO adsorption experiments, the sample was cooled down to 50 ºC in He. The background spectrum was recorded after 20 min of stabilization. After that, a mixture of CO/He (10/30 and 20/20 ml/min) was introduced for 20 min while recording the spectra. One additional spectrum was recorded at 100 ºC and 20/20 ml/min of CO/He. For the Fischer Tropsch synthesis experiments, the temperature was decreased to 220 ºC in He. After 20 min of stabilization and background recording, a syngas mixture, with the same H2/CO ratio as the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis experiments, consisting of He/H2/CO (20/13/7 ml/min) was introduced. After 20 min of spectra recording, the flow was switched to He and the temperature ramped to 240 ºC (1 K/min). The same procedure was followed and repeated at 260 ºC. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fischer-Tropsch synthesis In Fig. 1, the site−time yield (STY) based on H2 chemisorption, at fixed reaction conditions during the first 24 h on stream for all catalysts is depicted. The STY of unpromoted catalysts ranged from 0.6 s−1 to 0.35 s−1 with the catalyst CoRe/TiO2 displaying the highest activity and CoRe/SiO2−W, the lowest. The addition of Mn to the supports led to different behaviours. In the case of alumina supported catalysts, a trend was observed. An increase in Mn loading yielded higher intrinsic activity, at least after the initial lining out of the activity. For the narrow pore silica (SiO2−N), the STY showed a maximum at an Mn loading of 1.75 % Mn. Higher Mn loadings led to lower STY’s. The 5 % Mn−CoRe/SiO2−N showed the same STY as the unpromoted catalysts after the 24 h on stream, even though the initial specific activity was higher. Similarly, for the promoted and unpromoted catalysts supported on the wide pore silica SiO2−W, the Mn promotion gave a higher initial activity. But the STY of the 3.75 % Mn sample declined and was equal to that of the unpromoted sample after the first 24 h on stream. The TiO2−supported catalysts showed similar STY’s for the promoted (3,75 % Mn) and unpromoted sample. But for this support the unpromoted sample had a slightly higher specific activity. These results showed that Mn is an effective activity promoter for Co−based catalysts supported on Al2O3. However, the results on SiO2 and TiO2 are less clear. Morales et al. [23] also studied the Mn promotion of Co catalysts supported on TiO2 (Degussa P25). Their result depended on the preparation method. Catalysts prepared sequentially using HDP for the Co and subsequent IWI for the Mn showed an increase in the Co−time yield following the introduction of Mn, in contrast to the results that are presented in this work. But catalysts prepared using IWI for both Co and Mn showed a more complicated pattern of the activity. In this case the ranking of the catalysts in terms of the activity was dependent on the reduction temperature. Reduction at 300 °C gave catalysts with similar activity, but reduction at 350 °C favoured the sample where Mn was impregnated first. This catalyst was more active than the unpromoted sample, which in turn was more active than the sample where Mn was impregnated last. In a separate study, the same main authors [38], prepared similar catalysts using co−impregnation. Following reduction at 300 °C the activity was not significantly influenced by the absence or presence of Mn. The authors explained some of the effects observed as a consequence of the partial reducibility of the support, and the formation of mixed oxide phases. Den Breejen et al. in their work [28] with Co−Mn catalysts supported on silica (Grace−Davison Davicat 1454SI silica gel prepared via single pore−volume impregnation) studied two different heat treatments (in NO or air). Their results showed that depending on the heat treatment the addition of manganese could increase (NO treatment) or be detrimental (air) for the activity. They attributed the increase in activity due to a significant smaller Co crystallite size formed in the NO treated catalyst, as well as an increase in MnO dispersion. Nevertheless, this activity increase was linked to certain Co/Mn ratios. Above a Mn:Co ratio of 0.1, the addition of Mn was also unfavourable for the activity, attributed to blocking of Co active sites. In addition, the reduction procedure also influenced the performance of the catalysts. The unpromoted catalysts was more active following reduction at 450 ºC. Schröder et al. [36] prepared similar catalysts and their results showed a decrease in reaction rate with Mn addition. Similarly, Johnson et al. [29], prepared a Co−Mn catalyst supported on SiO2 (PQ Corp., CS−2129) via IWI with different Mn ratios. They found a volcano trend in the STY with an optimum Mn/Co ratio of 0.1, a similar value to that reported by Den Breejen et al. Pedersen et al. [8,30] examined CoMn catalysts supported on alumina and prepared by different IWI preparation methods. They found that only the catalysts which was prepared via two subsequent impregnation, first Mn and then Co, exhibited an increased activity. Bezemer et al. [37] studied the bimetallic catalysts supported on carbon nanofibers. They also found a small increase in STY with a specific Mn loading between 0.1 and 0.3 (corresponding to Mn:Co ratio of 0.01 and 0.03), lower quantities than in other studies. Another study [16] on CoMn on carbon nanotubes carried out by Thiessen et al., found that the activity was increased when the catalysts was prepared via co−impregnation but the activity was lower when the catalysts were prepared by subsequent impregnations. All these results suggest that the behaviour of manganese as an activity promoter for the Co catalyst depends on the preparation route. Increased activity is possible to achieve for many types of support and a wide range of loadings. However, the optimization of the loading, preparation method and catalyst activation are of great importance, in order to achieve an improvement in catalytic activity. The product distribution obtained at 50 % of CO conversion (obtained by adjusting the GHSV after 24 h on stream) is reported in Table 1. The unpromoted catalysts have similar product distribution at the same CO conversion, except for the SiO2−W catalyst which gave lower methane and a higher C5+ selectivity. The selectivity follows a trend with the loading of manganese. Manganese loadings up to 3.75 % led to a decreased the methane selectivity while increasing the apparent chain growth (C5+ selectivity). However, the 5Mn−CoRe/SiO2−N catalyst suffered a slight decrease in C5+ and increase in methane compared with the sample 3.75Mn−CoRe/SiO2−N. The manganese promotion of the selectivity appeared to be more pronounced in the silica and titania support compared to alumina. Methane decreased from 18.7 % to 8.3 % for the 3.75Mn−CoRe/SiO2−N, 12.9–6.6 % for 3.75Mn−CoRe/SiO2−W and 16.8–9.2 % 3.75Mn−CoRe/TiO2. In case of alumina−supported catalysts, the reduction in methane production was less prominent going from 19.2 % for the unpromoted catalyst to 13.5 % for 3.75Mn−CoRe/Al2O3. The C5+ selectivity followed the inverse trend of CH4 with an increased selectivity with more Mn loading suggesting that the increase is mainly due to a reduction in the selectivity to methane. In addition, the selectivity to light α−olefins also increases with the Mn loading, at the expense of the light paraffins. These results suggest a lower hydrogenation rate for the promoted catalysts, as seen in the olefin to paraffin ratio. The selectivity towards CO2 remained almost unchanged with a slight decrease in certain catalysts, discarding the possibility of Mn promoting the WGS reaction at these reaction conditions. A more in−depth analysis of the product distribution showed that the α−olefin increase depended on the chain−length. There were minor, but systematically positive changes in the light α−olefin selectivity from adding 3.75 % Mn on all supports. At the same time there was a decrease in the iso−olefin selectivity, and a decrease in the overall light olefin selectivity, linked to the increase in the alpha−value (chain growth probability). Several pathways are studied as mechanisms for chain growth, but it is widely accepted that a CH2 (or CHx) species is the monomer adding to the growing hydrocarbon chains according to the original carbide mechanism. These results suggest that the chain growth probability has not increased due to an increase rate in olefin re−adsorption, as the formation of paraffins are favoured by secondary olefin hydrogenation or is due to an increase in CO dissociation, which should have increased the CO conversion (activity) for all catalysts. Considering that the fundamental FTS reaction steps, initiation of chains, chain growth and chain termination, is believed to occur on low coordination sites, the increase in the STY might be attributed to an increase in these types of sites, at the expense of high coordination sites on which secondary reactions, such as methanation and olefin hydrogenation and isomerization, take place. As a result, the increase in chain growth is more likely to be caused by a decrease in H2 dissociation rate, giving relatively less methane and other paraffinic products. Most of the works mentioned before present the same trend with the addition of manganese, meaning an increase in chain growth. A wide range of explanations was suggested to account for the changes in the selectivity. Morales et at. [38–42] used HDP and they attributed the increase in C5+ to a decrease in Co reducibility based on the Co-Mn-Ti-O chemistry. Den Breejen [43] found an increase in chain growth which they attributed to an increased CHx coverage. Johnson [44,45] found that more Mn led to higher chain growth but reached a maximum with a Mn:Co ratio of 0.1. More Mn loading did not affect the selectivity. This effect was found to be pressure dependent, and they attributed the increase to an enhanced CO adsorption on altered active sites along the interface between Co and Mn. Bezemer [46,47] found an increase in C5+ which peaks at 0.3 % of Mn at atmospheric pressure and at 0.028 % Mn at 20 bar. Higher loadings of Mn did not increase further the chain growth but produced diminishing returns with a decrease in C5+. They assigned the behavior to a decrease in H2 coverage. Thiessen et al. reported a similar behavior. Lastly, Pedersen et al. [30] attributed the increase in chain growth due to an increase energy barrier for CH3 and CH4 formation. Contrary to this, Schröder [48] found that the addition of Mn led to a decrease in chain growth. The shift in selectivity was attributed to diffusion limitations within the catalyst pores, yielding a higher H2:CO ratio due to a higher diffusivity of hydrogen. However, some of the studies measured the product distributions at different CO conversions, which can affect the selectivity and influence the results. Our results, obtained at the same H2O partial pressure (CO conversion), supports most of the work. However, even with higher Mn loadings, the selectivity was shifted to longer hydrocarbon chains, here observed as a higher C5+ selectivity. 3.2 Textural and chemical properties Different experiments were performed to understand the textural and chemical properties with the addition of Mn. Results from N2 adsorption−desorption, H2 chemisorption, ex situ X − ray diffraction are summarized in Table 2. The surface characteristics of the pristine supports can be found in previous work [32]. γ−Al2O3 and both SiO2 supports have a relatively high surface area, but several differences might be found. γ−Al2O3 and SiO2−N have similar pore volume, but SiO2−N has a smaller average pore size, while SiO2−W has a similar pore size, but a higher pore volume when compared with γ−Al2O3. TiO2 is a low surface area support with meso− and macropores. Fig. 2 shows the pore size distribution of the pristine supports and the 3.75Mn−CoRe catalysts of all supports except for TiO2, excluded because it has aa larger pore size distribution, outside the range of precision of the N2 adsorption/desorption measurement. The pore size distribution of similar supports obtained by mercury intrusion is reported in other work [49]. The addition of the active materials in γ−Al2O3 decreased the surface area, pore volume and pore size evenly throughout the pore size distribution, suggesting that the Co particles are formed inside the wider pores of the support. On the other hand, the addition of the metals to SiO2−N, SiO2−W and TiO2 led to an even decrease in surface area and pore volume. However, the pore size remained constant, suggesting that the metal particles are uniformly distributed or outside of the pores. Hydrogen chemisorption experiments were carried out to calculate the Co dispersion based on previous work [50,51]. Based on previous studies [52–54], these results are outside the range where we expect to see effects of the particle size on the activity or selectivity of the Co catalysts. The results of the dispersion measurements were similar in all catalysts except the ones supported on TiO2, in the range D = 6 −8 %, corresponding to an average particle size around 12 −15 nm. The catalysts supported on TiO2 deviated from the trend with a larger Co particle size, around 25 nm, corresponding to a Co dispersion of about ∼4 %. A general trend is that the metal particle size increases in the same order as the pore size of the support. Interestingly, the exception is the catalysts supported on SiO2−N, which presented an average metallic particle size around 7 nm compared with a pore size 4.5 nm. Unlike the other supports, in which the Co particles appeared to be determined by the pore size, on the SiO2−N supports, the particles blocked pores and is assumed to form outside the measurable mesopores. Regarding the addition of Mn to the catalysts, no major differences or observable trends were observed in neither the physical parameters or the dispersion measurements between the promoted and unpromoted catalysts. These results suggest that the Co and manganese are not forming Co−Mn species, or that the species segregate after the reduction to form metallic cobalt, active for H2 dissociation. Otherwise, the changes in Co surface area would have affected the amount of H2 adsorbed. These results were also supported by the X − ray diffraction experiments. The X − ray diffractograms of all catalysts can be found in the supporting information, Figures S−1 to S−4. The diffractograms confirmed that Co3O4 is the only crystalline Co phase present in the calcined samples. Other phases observed are γ−Al2O3, amorphous SiO2 and a mixture of both TiO2 crystal phases, anatase and rutile, suggesting that the addition of manganese did not change the crystallinity of the Co oxide or support. No rhenium or manganese phases were detected indicating a high dispersion with particle sizes smaller than 3 nm. The most intense Co3O4 peak was used to calculate the crystallite size via the Scherrer equation, and metal oxide dispersion was obtained by Eq. 1 and converted to the corresponding metallic crystallite size by Eq. 2. The catalysts supported on Al2O3 exhibited similar but slightly smaller crystallite size values compared to those obtained by H2 chemisorption. Furthermore, in the same way as the particle size results found by H2 chemisorption, the crystallite size obtained by XRD was not affected by the promotion of Mn. This behaviour was also observed for the catalysts supported on SiO2−W and TiO2. On the other hand, the catalyst supported on SiO2−N, showed considerably smaller crystallite size than the particle size obtained by H2 chemisorption. Adding manganese to catalysts based on this support led to a decrease in the crystallite size, not dependent on the loading of promoter added to the catalysts. In the case of the alumina support, the Co particle size (∼12 nm) corresponds to the pore dimension, suggesting that the Co particles are forming inside the pores of the support and that the pore diameter controls the extension of the growth of the particles. A similar case occurred with SiO2−W and TiO2. On the other hand, Co particles on the SiO2−N support does not follow the same trend, presenting a similar Co particle size as the Co particles on alumina, in spite of having significantly smaller pores. These results suggest that the particles are formed outside the pore structure of the support. It is also possible that the silica support contains macropores, not measured by N2 adsorption−desorption, and that the particles are formed in those types of pores. The reducibility of the catalysts was studied by temperature programmed reduction for all catalysts. In Fig. 3, the TPR profile of the unpromoted and 3.75Mn promoted catalysts are depicted. In addition, the TPR-profiles of the intermediate materials impregnated with only 3.75Mn on Al2O3 and SiO2−N supports are also reported. The manganese (alone) reduction profile on both alumina and silica showed a bimodal distribution with a major peak at 310 ºC and 280 ºC respectively and a minor peak at 390 ºC for both supports. This can be interpreted as a two-step reduction of Mn oxide. The first and largest peak represents the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3 and Mn3O4, and the second peak could be further reduction to MnO. The differences in the peak temperature for the first peak might be due to a different interaction between the MnO2 and the support material. Smaller manganese particles more difficult to reduce might be formed on Al2O3 due to a stronger interaction with the support. The TPR profile of the Co catalysts supported on Al2O3, showed mainly a bimodal distribution with peak temperatures at 340 ºC and 450 ºC corresponding to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and further reduction of CoO to Co0 [55,56]. The profile also contains two smaller shoulders at 230 ºC, attributed to the reduction of metal nitrate residues, indicating incomplete decomposition of the nitrate salts during calcination, and shoulders at approx. 500 ºC, possibly due to more strongly interacting Co particles. No major differences were observed from the addition of manganese. In the case of SiO2−N, the profile presented the same main features as the Al2O3 catalysts was the unpromoted catalysts, but with slightly lower reduction temperatures with peaks at 300 ºC and 400 ºC. In addition, the 3.75Mn promoted catalyst presented a more intense nitrates peak and a notable increase in the high temperature peak. This increase might be due to the smaller pores of the support, yielding smaller Co particles more difficult to reduce [57]. Another possible reason is the formation of less reducible cobalt−silicate species [58]. The SiO2−W catalysts exhibited reduction peaks at the same temperature as the catalysts supported on the other SiO2−N support. However, SiO2−W, with wider pores, did not show the increase and prominent shoulder on the high temperature peak, suggesting that the pore structure might be the cause of the less reducible Co oxide present in the 3.75Mn−CoRe/SiO2−N. However, the shoulder was slightly more prominent in the Mn promoted catalyst. Finally, the catalysts supported on TiO2, presented a similarly shaped TPR−profile as the other catalysts, but with peak temperatures in between the SiO2 and Al2O3. These results are in agreement with different studies regarding the metal−support interaction strength in which the strength of interaction increases in the following order: SiO2<TiO2<Al2O3 [14,59]. No shoulder at high temperature was detected for the TiO2-supported catalysts, but the Mn promoted sample exhibited a shift in the peak to higher temperatures. The addition of manganese did affect the reducibility of the catalyst. This effect was previously reported by other studies. The decrease in reducibility has been attributed to the presence of Co−Mn interactions [18,23]. The decrease in reducibility in our study was considerably lower compared with other works, suggesting that the synthesis method and treatment is of strong importance for the final catalytic characteristics. Furthermore, this effect was more prominent on SiO2 and TiO2 than compared to Al2O3. The stronger interactions between Al2O3 and Co compared with TiO2 and SiO2 might be the reason behind the lower interactions between Co−Mn in this support. 3.3 Adsorption properties and operando−DRIFTS DRIFTS spectra were recorded during CO adsorption and CO hydrogenation over the unpromoted and promoted catalysts for all supports studied. The nature and state of the catalytic surface can be studied by the gas−phase probe molecules, as CO, adsorbing on active sites. Changes in the adsorption properties following modifications of the surface, as the case of the promotion with Mn, might reveal the mechanism by which the promotion is achieved. In this case might the nature of the metallic surface affect the electronic state of the adsorbed CO. Significantly electron dense surfaces can back−donate electrons to the 2π antibonding orbital of the CO. This will cause a red−shift in the vibrational transitions of CO due to a weakened bond. On the other hand, electron acceptor surfaces can decrease the bond energy of CO caused by sigma−donation from CO to the surface, returning a blue−shift in frequency [60]. In order to study the manganese promotion, two different experiments were conducted. Adsorption using CO as probe molecule alone, and CO and H2 adsorption at FTS reaction conditions. Due to the difficulty of quantitative analysis using DRIFTS due to different particle sizes and packing, only qualitative analysis was performed in this work. The identification of the different absorption bands has been previously discussed based on prior studies. The rotational/vibrational transitions of gas phase CO are visible around 2200 −2100 cm−1. For the CO adsorption experiments, three different regions of the spectra were discussed. First, the stretching vibration of linearly bonded CO region at the regions discussed between 2100 −2000 cm−1. Secondly, the bridge−bonded CO, or CO adsorbed onto two analogous metal sites, between 2000 −1700 cm−1. Lastly, the 1700 −1200 cm−1 region corresponding to the formation of bonded oxygenates as acetates, formates, carboxylates, etc. and to −CH− deformations. In addition, for the in situ−DRIFTS experiments, the absorption band between 3100 cm−1 and 2800 cm−1 attributed to the stretching of hydrocarbon (−CH−) species [61–63,66] was also discussed. First, CO adsorption experiments were carried out on the unpromoted and promoted samples by DRIFTS to understand the nature of the Mn promotion. The results are shown in Fig. 4A, with a magnification of the spectra between the wavenumber 2150 and 2000 cm−1 to show the differences in the vibrations of the linearly bonded CO in Fig. 4B. The experiments done at different CO partial pressure (20 −20 ml/min CO/He) did not significantly affect the spectra, with an increase in intensity in all the peaks, therefore the results are not shown here but they can be found in the supporting information, Figures S−5 to S−8. The CO adsorption experiments performed at 100 ºC (20 −20 ml/min CO/He) are also found in the supporting information. All the spectra were normalized to the gas−phase CO transitions around 2160 cm−1 assuming the same CO partial pressure. Most of the catalysts presented similar spectra with a correlation between the integrated area of the bonded CO and the dispersion measured by H2 chemisorption. The Mn-promoted catalyst supported on Al2O3 presented a small redshift in the linearly bonded CO combined with an increase in intensity, while the bridge−bonded region remained unchanged when compared with the unpromoted sample on the same support. A signal at 1650 cm−1 was detected, and this can possibly be attributed to adsorbed water. This interpretation is supported by features around 3600 cm−1 indicating the presence of adsorbed water (not shown) [64]. Interestingly, only the catalysts supported on alumina exhibited these peaks. Regarding the catalysts supported on the narrow pore SiO2−N, a small increase in the peak corresponding to linearly bonded CO was detected but no red−shift or changes in the bridge−bonded CO were observed. The spectra of catalysts supported on SiO2−W did not significantly change with the Mn addition. Finally, the spectra of the catalyst supported on TiO2 presented major differences. On one hand, the unpromoted catalyst exhibited three peaks in the range of wavenumbers normally attributed to linearly bonded CO (2050, 2070 and 2100 cm−1). The promoted catalysts spectrum was similar to the spectra recorded on silica and alumina-supported samples, but with a rather weaker intensity. The different peaks in the unpromoted catalysts might be due to metallic Co with different adsorption properties or crystallite phases [15]. But, the presence of multi-carbonyl species explaining bands close to 2100 cm−1 has also been suggested [65,67]. Another possibility is the CO adsorption on support-modified sites. However, these differences disappear with the addition of manganese. This suggests that, with the addition of manganese, Co preferentially forms certain types of crystalline structures, which is in line with the proposal by den Brejeen et al. [28], who reported that Mn induced the formation of low−index Co crystals. A further possibility is that the initial calcination of Mn−TiO2, to produce the intermediate material 3.75Mn/TiO2, altered the phases of the support leading to the formation of a different type of Co crystallite. Considering the activity or selectivity of the catalysts in relation to the obtained spectra, no significant trend is evident. Other studies [24] considered manganese as an electronic promoter affecting the CO adsorption. Manganese will be present in the catalysts as Mn2+, lowering the electron density and resulting in a blue−shift in the frequency of the vibrational stretching of linearly bonded CO [20,24,29]. In our results, the Mn promoted catalyst supported on alumina showed a red−shift. Hence, our results suggest that Mn is acting as a weak Lewis acid, increasing the back−donation from the metal decreasing the bond energy of CO, similar to the findings of Visser et al. [21]. This decrease in bond energy might be the reason behind the increase in activity. From the activity results, 3.75Mn−CoRe/Al2O3 showed a higher promotion effect in the activity. However, no strong conclusion might be drawn from the CO adsorption experiments alone. To further investigate the promotion, operando FTS DRIFTS was also performed. Three different temperatures were studied (220 ºC, 240 ºC and 260 ºC) for all the catalysts. Fig. 5 depicts the spectra obtained during FTS of the catalysts CoRe/Al2O3 and 3.75Mn−CoRe/Al2O3 at the three different temperatures, after the spectrum was stabilized. The complete time resolved sets of DRIFT spectra can be found in the supporting information, Figures S−9 to S−20. Similarly, Fig. 6 illustrates the spectra of CoRe/SiO2−N and 3.75Mn−CoRe/SiO2−N. The spectra obtained for the unpromoted and 3.75 −Mn promoted catalysts supported on TiO2 and SiO2−W can be found in the supporting information, Figures S−21 to S−32. The experiments consisted of 20 min of syngas flow (7 ml/min CO/13 ml/min H2) with DRIFTS spectra recorded every minute. After 20 min the temperature was ramped up to the next desired temperature in He flow. Considering the stretching vibration of linearly bonded CO a blue−shift is seen, increasing with time until maximum coverage is reached. This effect is attributed to a decrease in π−back−bonding from Co0 due to the increase in CO coverage [69]. The increased coverage results in fewer Co atoms donating electron density to each CO, yielding the observed blue shift. The increase in temperature to 240 ºC surprisingly increased the linearly bonded CO peak, but a further increase in temperature to 260 ºC led to a less intense peak and a red−shift compared with the peak at 240 °C. This behaviour is expected in light of the exothermic nature of the adsorption, and since at higher temperatures just the stronger bounded CO will be present. The opposite effect between 220 °C and 240 °C could be a kinetic effect, or an artifact induced, e.g. by small changes in the optical pathlength [73]. At 260 ºC, irreversible CO adsorption can be seen. The increase in temperature also broadened the peaks [70]. Regarding the bridge bonded CO, a decrease in the ratio between linearly−to−bridge bonded CO was found with increased temperature. The linear−to−bridge bonded ratio (L/B ratio) has been used to correlate the electronic structure with catalytic activity [71–75]. This will be discussed further below. The region between 3100 and 2700 corresponds to the C−H stretching bands. The band at 2960 cm−1 is assigned to asymmetric stretch of CH3 terminal groups. The band at 2925 cm−1 is assigned to asymmetric stretch of saturated CH2 groups. Finally, the band at 2890 and 2855 cm−1 are assigned to symmetric stretches of CH3 and CH2 respectively [76]. The hydrocarbon bands decreased in intensity with increased temperature suggesting a faster desorption at higher temperatures. However, after the experiment, hydrocarbons remained adsorbed on the surface, probably as wax products or intermediate products (growing chains) remaining on the surface after the removal of the syngas. The ratio between asymmetric CH2 and CH3 bands is higher than unity, meaning that long chained hydrocarbons are produced. Furthermore, the decrease in ratio with higher temperature points to a lower chain growth probability, which is in agreement with temperature dependency of the alpha value. Lastly, the region between 1700 and 1300 cm−1, corresponding to the adsorbed oxygenated species presented different bands depending on the support and their assignment is described below. One common feature for all catalysts is the decrease of these bands with the increased temperature and the presence of the bands after the elimination of the syngas flow, similarly to the hydrocarbon bands, perhaps indicating that, at least some of these bands, represent species that are not associated with the catalytic mechanism leading to hydrocarbons. The addition of manganese led to small differences in the obtained spectra. In the case of alumina supported catalysts, a redshift in the linearly bonded CO can be seen with the manganese promotion. The decrease in intensity and broadening due to increased temperature is more pronounced in the promoted catalysts, implying that the addition of manganese led to a more strongly adsorbed CO or an increased rate of dissociation of CO to adsorbed C* and O*. This effect might be the reason behind the increase in hydrocarbon formation. More strongly adsorbed CO could shift the CO−to−H2 coverage ratio in the catalyst surface, favouring the chain growth and olefin selectivity. In addition, the L/B ratio decreases with the addition of manganese pointing to an increase in the electron density of the catalysts. This increase in electron density will increase the back−donation from the surface to CO, decreasing the bond strength of the CO. This decrease in L/B ratio means that CO is more preferentially adsorbed in bridge coordination rather than linearly bonded with the addition of manganese. Several studies have reported that bridge bonded CO is an active intermediate species [77–80]. In addition, Mojet et al. [68] found a relationship between catalytic activity and the L/B ratio for PT/zeolites. They attributed the increase in activity to a better overlapping of the metal d−orbitals and the CO resulting in a better electron density transfer. In that sense, the decrease in L/B ratio means a higher backdonation and therefore, a higher decrease in CO bonding energy. This preferential adsorption in bridge coordination could increase the hydrocarbon formation rate yielding the higher chain growth observed with the Mn promotion as a result of this enhanced electron backdonation. This increase in chain growth probability is evident from catalytic results and can be seen in the ratio between absorbance attributed to CH2/CH3 asymmetric stretches. The addition of manganese led to a higher ratio indicating that more CH2 intermediates are produced with the promoter present on the surface. Lastly, the oxygenate regions presented differences between the promoted and unpromoted catalysts. For Mn−promoted Al2O3 supported catalysts, infrared bands are evident at 1630, 1600, 1588 cm−1 for the first region, 1460 cm−1 for the second, and at 1392, 1379 and 1372 cm−1 for the last region. However, the unpromoted catalysts did not show bands at 1630 cm−1. The 1588 and 1372 cm−1 peaks can be attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric O−C−O stretching vibration of adsorbed formate species [81]. The peak at 1392 cm−1 can then be attributed to the C−H deformations of the surface formate species [81]. The band at 1460 cm−1 might be attributed to different species. On one hand, it can be due to asymmetric unidentate carbonate complexes [82], with the corresponding symmetric peak at 1370 cm−1. The C−H deformations of CH2 and CH3 [83] might be also included in the peak at 1460 cm−1 or this could be due to the simple carbonate ion CO 3 2 − [84,85]. The peaks at 1630 and 1600 cm−1 are assigned to bidentate carbonate species or bridge−bonded carbonate complexes [82]. An increase in oxygenated compounds, seen as stronger IR peaks, was also observed in the promoted Al2O3 -supported catalysts but it was more pronounced in the peak at around 1630 cm−1 assigned to bidentate carbonate species or bridge−bonded carbonate complexes, suggesting that the reaction mechanism is different with the addition of manganese. However, the involvement of this species in the reaction is not clear and its presence did not appear to have an influence on the overall selectivity, thus indicating that these species are spectators to the actual FTS reaction. These species remained adsorbed even after the syngas flow was stopped. Furthermore, the peak at 1630 cm−1 increases in relative intensity after stopping the syngas flow suggesting that the species is mobile under certain conditions, moving from one configuration to another. In the catalysts supported on SiO2 and TiO2 similar adsorption bands were observed. However, similarly as observed for the alumina supported catalysts, the bands grew in intensity upon Mn promotion, possibly due to the decrease in CO bond energy observed before. For the SiO2 supported catalysts only a broad peak at 1582 cm−1 was observed, assigned to the O−C−O stretching vibration of adsorbed formate species. Below 1500 cm−1, the signal to noise ratio decreased, masking any band below that wavenumber. Due to the absence of the other bands in the SiO2 support, this absorption band is attributed to the interaction between the alumina and titania support and the CO and H2. Therefore, these species were considered inactive for FTS. In Fig. 7, the DRIFTS spectra obtained from the Mn-promoted catalysts on the different supports at 240 ºC is presented and compared. Similar behaviour was found for all of the catalysts. A small blue shift in the linearly bonded CO was observed for the catalysts supported on both SiO2−supports compared to Al2O3 and TiO2. This difference was also observed by Chin et al. [85]. The difference in metal−support interactions influences the charge of the surface. Interestingly, this shift would be expected from the influence of Lewis acids and SiO2 is thought to behave as a neutral support. However, no observable trend was observed with different supports regarding linearly bonded CO and this shift was not translated into an apparent influence on the activity or selectivity. On the other hand, only the catalysts supported on Al2O3 exhibited a significantly more intense band for bridge bonded CO compared to SiO2 and TiO2. This catalyst additionally gave the lower C5+ selectivity, indicating lower chain growth probability. In TiO2 and SiO2 supported catalysts, the bridge bonded region is almost flat, in contrast to the experiments with CO adsorption. This difference with the addition of hydrogen might be due to a fast conversion of bridge bonded adsorbed CO species to hydrocarbons intermediates in the chain growth process. It could also be due to the unavailability of sites due to competitive adsorption of H2, this is however less likely since CO is adsorbed stronger. This increased rate might also be reflected in the higher selectivity to C5+ products of the catalysts supported on SiO2 and TiO2. In summary, manganese appears to act as an electronic promoter, increasing the electron density of the Co particles and decreasing the bond strength of the CO, leading to an increase in the selectivity to higher hydrocarbons. The reason behind why the manganese influences the activity in some cases but not on all supports might be due to a balance between the decrease in CO bond energy (enhancing the activity) and the blocking of Co active sites by manganese particles (reducing the number of sites and hence the activity). In that sense, the 1.75Mn−CoRe/SiO2−N might be near an optimum Mn loading; providing the electronic promotion by Mn, but the lower loading blocking fewer active sites, resulting in a more active catalysts compared to the 3.75Mn−CoRe/SiO2−N. The blockage of Co particle by manganese can be seen in the reduction of dispersion measured by H2 chemisorption. A slightly higher wavenumber was observed in the vibration of linearly bonded CO on the 3.75Mn−CoRe/Al2O3 DRIFTS spectra compared with the other supports. However, this blue−shift in the CO absorption band was not correlated with lower activity compared with 3.75Mn−CoRe/SiO2−N, which presented a similar STY with a lower linearly bonded CO vibrational frequency. Therefore, it is likely that the observed frequencies of the linearly bonded CO studied by DRIFTS are not a valid measure of the activity or expected product distribution of catalysts supported on different materials. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the manganese promotion clearly has an effect on the Co catalysts, especially on the selectivity but also on the activity. This effect works by electronic modification of the Co environment, reducing the bond strength of the CO by an increased back−donation of electron density from the Co to the antibonding 2π orbital. The result is an increase in the chain growth probability, and it could mean an increase in the intrinsic activity as well, but this could be masked by site blocking. In our study, the promoted catalysts supported on Al2O3 exhibited an increase in STY, alkene production and chain growth probability. In the case of the catalysts supported on the narrow pore silica (SiO2−N), lower loadings of Mn (1.75 %), yielded an increase in activity and enhanced selectivity. Higher Mn loadings (3.75 %) decreased the activity of the catalysts but increased the chain growth probability further. Finally, the catalysts with the highest Mn loading (5 %) exhibited an even lower STY and a decrease in α−value compared to the previous catalysts. In the case of the catalysts supported on wide pore silica and titania, the only effect observed was an increase in the chain growth probability, seen as an increased C5 + selectivity. From these results, it is clear that the pore structure of the support and the interactions between the support and the Co plays a role in achieving the optimal manganese promotion. Higher manganese loadings might reduce the bond energy of the CO, but at the same time, decrease the availability of Co active sites, resulting in no overall promotion of the activity. coredata.dc:description: The manganese promotion of cobalt−based catalysts for the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis was investigated using four different supports. Different loadings of manganese were deposited on the catalysts using incipient wetness impregnation before the impregnation of cobalt and rhenium. All the Mn-promoted catalysts exhibited an increase in chain growth probability and olefin content in the products. This enhanced C5+ selectivity is attributed mainly to decreased methane production. The promotion of the catalytic activity was dependent on the support material. On γ−Al2O3 the catalyst activity increased with increasing manganese loading. Using a narrow pore silica support (SiO2−N) a maximum in the activity was found at an intermediate manganese loading. Further addition of Mn decreased the activity and worsened the product distribution with an increase in methane selectivity. The catalysts supported on TiO2 and wide pore silica (SiO2−W), did not show major activity changes with Mn addition. The addition of Mn decreased the metallic surface area in most cases, indicating blocking of Co sites. The pore structure and the metal−support interactions play a role in how the Mn and Co are dispersed, yielding enhanced or inhibited activity. The origin of the promotion was investigated with CO and syngas adsorption experiments coupled with recording DRIFTS spectra. The results indicated a decrease in CO bond energy due to an increase in electron density of the Co with the Mn addition. The electronic effect appeared to be in balance with the site blocking of Mn. Therefore, choice of support and preparation conditions of the materials are important.
